tossups.question: This thinker’s labor theory of property says that the right to property comes from physical exertion upon natural resources. In one work, this thinker gave a sentence-by-sentence rebuttal of Robert Filmer’s Patriarcha. This philosopher outlined three components of a good education in (*) Some Thoughts Concerning Education. This thinker argued that the human mind begins as a “tabula rasa,” or blank slate, in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding. For ten points, name this English philosopher who argued that man’s natural rights include life, liberty, and property in Two Treatises on Government.

A poet from this country wrote “From the cold niche / I will lower you to the humble and sunny ground” in a collection addressed to their dead lover Romelio Ureta. A poet from this country described “the mad impulse” to put a gift from Maru Mori “in a golden / cage” in a collection which contains poems about Arthur Rimbaud and Àngel Cruchaga. The author of Sonnets of Death is from this country, where another poet wrote about household objects in the (*) Elemental Odes. That poet from this country also wrote “tonight I can write the saddest lines” in Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair. For ten points, name this home country of Gabriela Mistral and Pablo Neruda.

George Biggar was killed by these people near the town of Weenen. Nathaniel Isaacs wrote a history emphasizing the cruelty of a leader of these people. After massacring the travelling party of Piet Reitief, these people were defeated by forces under Andres Pretorius at the Battle of (*) Blood River. These people underwent a period of forced dispersal known as the Mfecane [meh-fuh-can-ee], and they used a spear called the assegai. Troops under Lord Chelmsford were massacred by these people’s “buffalo horn” formation at Isandlwana [is-and-ell-wan-a], but they still lost an arduous war to the British. For ten points, name these South African people unified by Shaka.

Temperatures of metal oxides are plotted against this quantity in an Ellingham diagram. The partial derivative of this quantity with respect to particle number is equal to the chemical potential of a system. This quantity can be expressed as negative R T times the natural log of the (*) equilibrium constant. For a voltaic cell, this quantity is equal to negative n F times the cell potential. This quantity is equal to the change in enthalpy minus the product of the change in entropy and temperature. For ten points, name this quantity named for an American scientist that is negative for spontaneous reactions.
tossups.answer: Gibbs free energy [accept change in Gibbs free energy; prompt on G or delta G]
tossups.answer_formatted: Gibbs free energy [accept change in Gibbs free energy; prompt on G or delta G]

tossups.question: A species of woodpecker known as this region’s namesake flicker can be found at Sajama National Park. A bright orange and black bird species known as the Cock-of-the-Rock can be found in cloud forests of this mountain range. A prime flamingo breeding ground is located in a massive salt flat in this mountain range known as (*) Salar de Uyuni. Vicuñas can be found living in a plateau region of this mountain range known as the altiplano. This mountain range contains Lake Titicaca, which straddles the border of Bolivia and Peru. For ten points, llamas are native to what mountain range that runs along the western side of South America?

In a painting titled for this country, a man's hand peeks out from rubble in the foreground while a bare-chested woman kneels. Gericault’s Raft of the Medusa inspired another painting set in this country that depicts thirteen islanders being rounded up to be massacred. This country is the setting of The Massacre at (*) Chios and is depicted “On the Ruins of Missolonghi” in two works by Delacroix. A David painting set in this country depicts a king leading a force of three hundred against the Persian army. For ten points, name this European country, the setting of David's Leonidas at Thermopylae, which depicts a Spartan king.

In a novel by this author, Medardo is sewn back together after being split in two by a cannonball. The omnipresent being Qfwfq [“koof-ka”] narrates a scientifically-inspired collection by this author. A character created by this author seeks the help of Professor Uzzi-Tuzii in the fictional country of Cimmeria. This author of The Cloven Viscount and Cosmicomics wrote about (*) Marco Polo talking about the title entities with Kublai Khan. In a novel by this author, odd-numbered chapters are written in second-person narrative and includes You, the reader as its main protagonist. For ten points, name this Italian author of Invisible Cities and If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler.

This person visited a relative in an event known as the Visitation. A request by this person prompted a miracle performed during the Wedding at Cana. This person makes the declaration, “I am the Lord’s servant” to Gabriel during the Annunciation, and gives a prayer known as the (*) Magnificat after another event. This person underwent Dormition before her Assumption. The idea that this woman lived her entire life free of original sin is referred to as the Immaculate Conception. For ten points, name this biblical woman who was married to Joseph and is said to have given birth to Jesus while still remaining a virgin.
tossups.answer: Mary [or Maryam, or Mariam, or Theotokos]

tossups.question: These mathematical objects are called “Cauchy” [KOH-shee] when their terms become arbitrarily close past some value. They’re not functions, but these objects can be interpreted as mappings from the natural numbers to n-dimensional space. A specific one of these objects has a closed-form solution given by Binet’s formula, whose limiting ratio of successive terms is the (*) golden ratio. These non-function objects converge if their terms approach a limiting value. These objects can be recursively defined, and repeatedly adding terms of these objects gives a series. For ten points, name these ordered collections of values, such as one named for Fibonacci.

A leader of this colony negotiated with Chief Tomochichi of the Yamacraw Indians to establish Fort Frederica and established a “trustee system” in this colony that banned lawyers. Forces under the leader of this colony won the Battle of Bloody Marsh during the War of Jenkins’ Ear. The (*) southernmost commercial port of the Thirteen Colonies was this colony’s capital of Savannah. The British used this debtors’ haven as a buffer zone against Spanish Florida. For ten points, name this colony founded by James Oglethorpe that contains modern-day cities like Atlanta.

In one of these places, a character kills a hound using a Burmese tiger pit after being told that “life is for the strong.” A story named for one of these places sees Edward Prendick discover the title character’s experiments with creating animal-human hybrids. In a Richard Connell short story set in one of these places named (*) “Ship-Trap,” Rainsford is pursued by the cossacks Ivan and Zaroff. In a novel titled for one of these places, Jim Hawkins and Long John Silver follow Captain Flint’s map. Dr. Moreau lives on, for ten points, what kind of location that in a novel by Robert Louis Stevenson novel contains treasure.
tossups.answer: islands [accept Treasure Island, accept Ship-Trap Island, accept The Island of Doctor Moreau]
tossups.answer_formatted: islands [accept Treasure Island, or Ship-Trap Island, or The Island of Doctor Moreau]

tossups.question: One rebellion named for these things fought against Emperor Qianlong and attempted to restore the Ming Dynasty to power. These things name a series of ritual wars to capture sacrifices for the sun god, often undertaken against the neighboring Tlaxcala by the Aztec Triple-Alliance. Another war named for a variety of these things included the Battle of (*) Saint Albans and the Battle of Bosworth Field, where Henry VII killed Richard III and established the Tudor Dynasty. The first known speculative bubble was over a type of these things and took place in Holland in the 17th century. For ten points, name this type of plant, varieties of which include lotuses, roses and tulips.
tossups.answer: flowers [accept lotuses, roses, or tulips until mentioned, accept Flower Wars]
tossups.answer_formatted: flowers [accept lotuses, roses, or tulips until mentioned, or Flower Wars]

tossups.question: The protagonist of one opera by this composer is arrested after stabbing a woman, but sings a seguidilla [seh-guh-DEE-ya] in order to convince a guard to let her escape. Nadir and Zurga sing the duet “Au fond du temple saint” [ow fond du TOM-pleh SAWN] as they reminisce on their friendship in this composer’s The (*) Pearl Fishers. Escamillo is lauded for winning a bullfight as Don José [zhoh-say] stabs the title cigarette factory worker in this composer’s most performed opera. The title character of that opera sings about the qualities of love using a habanera. For ten points, name this French composer of Carmen.
tossups.answer: Georges Bizet [or Alexandre César Léopold Bizet]

tossups.question: A group from this state fronted by the rapper Scarface recorded the song “Mind Playing Tricks on Me.” The Geto Boys were from this state, as is an artist who memorialized a DJ from it on his song “R.I.P. Screw.” That song appears on an album titled for a closed amusement park in this state and includes a single on which an artist from this state raps about “Nike Boys hoppin out (*) coupes” and mixes that “pop like Jamba Juice.” That artist from this state released a 2020 collaboration with McDonalds and included the single “Sicko Mode” on his album Astroworld. For ten points, name this home state of Travis Scott, a Houston native.

A “March” for these people appears in Act 3 of Handel’s oratorio Saul. One piece for piano and orchestra about these people, a “Paraphrase on Dies Irae,” is Franz Liszt’s Totentanz. Four offstage brass bands are included in a Berlioz piece titled “The Grand Mass” for these people. An oboe signals the sunrise in a piece in which these people, represented by xylophones, are invited to (*) dance during the night. The tone poem Danse Macabre depicts these people rising from their graves on Halloween. Requiems are masses composed for, for ten points, what kind of people who are honored at funerals?
tossups.answer: dead people [or equivalents; accept skeletons or ghosts]

tossups.question: These entities may cluster together to form metabolon complexes in order to facilitate channeling. One model that describes these entities uses the constants Km [K-sub-m] and Vmax [V-sub-max] and assumes the quasi-steady-state approximation. That model is named for Michaelis and Menten. The structure of these molecules is altered by attachment of effector molecules in (*) allosteric regulation. Restriction types of these molecules can be used to cleave DNA at specific sites. These molecules can be inhibited by competitive binding with their substrate. For ten points, name these proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions by lowering the activation energy.
tossups.answer: enzymes [prompt on catalysts until it is mentioned]

tossups.question: This novel's protagonist breaks her leg in two places while skiing with a man who compares poetry to dust. Earlier in this novel, the main character drinks water from the finger bowl of the author Philomela Guinea, who pays for her stay in a location where she reunites with Joan Gilling. This novel's main character dates a Yale doctor recovering from tuberculosis in Vermont, (*) Buddy Willard. This novel begins during the "queer sultry summer" when the Rosenbergs were executed, during which the protagonist interns at Ladies' Day magazine in New York City. For ten points, name this novel about Esther Greenwood's mental illness, the only novel of Sylvia Plath.

The Algonquin people believed that one of these creatures fought the underwater panther or Great Horned Serpent that ruled the underworld. In Lenape mythology, a rainbow one of these animals turns black after bringing fire to earth to melt snow. The Qixi festival celebrates a day when a cowherd and a weaver girl were reunited by a (*) bridge made of these animals. Heracles used krotala to scare off some of these animals, which lived in a swamp in Stymphalia during his sixth labor. One of these animals is said to be reborn from its own ashes every five hundred years, and is called a phoenix. For ten points, swans, magpies, and crows are what kind of avian creatures?

The magnitude of one type of this effect is equal to the square root of 1 plus beta over 1 minus beta. Broadening of spectral lines due to this effect is caused by a nonuniform velocity distribution of particles. Canal rays with the required Lorentz symmetry underwent the relativistic form of this effect in the (*) Ives-Stilwell experiment. This effect is used to identify the direction in which stars are moving based on their redshift and blueshift. This effect is commonly used to explain the change in pitch and volume of ambulance sirens. For ten points, identify this phenomenon responsible for the change in frequency of a wave for an observer when the source moves.
tossups.answer: Doppler effect [or Doppler shift; accept transverse Doppler effect or relativistic Doppler effect; accept redshift or blueshift until they are mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: Doppler effect [or Doppler shift; accept transverse Doppler effect or relativistic Doppler effect; accept redshift or blueshift until they are mentioned]

tossups.question: This non-English ruler received the Chinese Jesuit Michael Shen Fu-Tsung, who taught this ruler’s court how to use chopsticks and write Chinese characters. This ruler banished Jews from his country’s colonies and established rules for slavery in the Black Code. In order to boost his country’s economy, this monarch banned Venetian glass exports, and during his childhood, this ruler survived the (*) Fronde rebellion. In the War of Devolution, this man expanded his country’s territory, resulting in the formation of the Triple Alliance opposition. This ruler decreased the influence of nobles by forcing them to live at Versailles. For ten points, name this “Sun King” of France.
tossups.answer: Louis XIV of France [accept Louis the Great; prompt on Sun King before mention; prompt on Louis]
tossups.answer_formatted: Louis XIV of France [accept Louis the Great; prompt on Sun King before mention; prompt on Louis]

tossups.question: One character in this novel is entertained by a “pinchbug” while attending a church service. Another character in this work brings a dead cat to a graveyard at midnight in an attempt to ward off evil spirits and witnesses the murder of Dr. Robinson during a robbery. One character in this work refuses a gift of a brass knob when she discovers the main character was previously “engaged” to Amy Lawrence; that character is (*) Becky Thatcher. The title character of this work is assigned to whitewash a fence by his Aunt Polly due to his prior mischief. For ten points, name this novel in which the title character discovers gold in McDougal’s Cave with Huck Finn, a work of Mark Twain.

bonuses.leadin: A player of this instrument helped popularize jazz in a famous concert at Carnegie Hall in 1938. For ten points each:
parts: Name this woodwind instrument played by Benny Goodman. This instrument famously plays a glissando at the opening of George Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue.

Goodman had a long rivalry with this bandleader whose Concerto for Clarinet ends with a high altissimo C. This clarinetist rose to popularity by arranging and recording Cole Porter’s song “Begin the Beguine.” [beh-GEEN]

Artie Shaw primarily composed and played in this genre of jazz, of which Benny Goodman was known as “the King.” Count Basie and Duke Ellington led a revival of this type of jazz following its decline in popularity.

bonuses.leadin: A band-pass filter commonly contains one of these electrical systems at its resonant frequency. For ten points each:
answers: LC circuit [or LC oscillator; accept RLC circuit or RLC oscillator; accept, BUT DO NOT REVEAL, inductor-capacitor circuit]
parts: Name these electrical circuits whose total stored energy harmonically oscillates between an electric and magnetic field. These circuits are electrically analogous to a tuning fork and are damped from the addition of a resistor.

An LC circuit consists of a capacitor and one of these circuit components, which are described by Faraday’s law. These components store energy in a magnetic field and their namesake unit is measured in Henrys.
The voltage across an inductor is proportional to the time derivative of this quantity. This quantity is itself the time derivative of charge and measures the flow of electricity in a region.
answers_formatted: LC circuit [or LC oscillator; accept RLC circuit or RLC oscillator; accept accept, BUT DO NOT REVEAL, inductor-capacitor circuit]
acceptable: accept, BUT DO NOT REVEAL, inductor-capacitor circuit

bonuses.leadin: This character is discussed by two other characters in Red Sammy’s diner and is assisted by Hiram and Bobby Lee. For ten points each:
answers: “A Good Man is Hard to Find”
Southern United States [or the South; accept Southern Gothic]
parts: Name this criminal who, after shooting another character, remarks that “she would’ve been a good woman if it had been somebody there to shoot her every minute of her life.”
The Misfit shoots the grandmother in this short story by Flannery O’Connor. In this story, the grandmother’s family encounters the Misfit after getting into a car accident.

O’Connor’s works were in a Gothic genre named for this geographic region, where the events of “A Good Man is Hard to Find” takes place. Other authors that wrote about this region include Mississippi native Eudora Welty.
answers_formatted: “A Good Man is Hard to Find”
acceptable: “A Good Man is Hard to Find”

bonuses.leadin: This ruler defeated Llewellyn the Last to conquer Wales. For ten points each:
answers: Edward I [accept Edward Longshanks, prompt on Edward]
barons [accept the First or Second Baron’s Wars]
parts: Name this ruler who won the Battle of Falkirk and was nicknamed the “Hammer of the Scots.” This ruler earned their most famous epithet from their lanky appearance.

Members of this religious group were forced to leave England after Edward Longshanks signed the Edict of Expulsion in 1290. Members of this religious group were accused of using the blood of English children to make matzah for their holiday of Passover.

Edward Longshanks secured his succession of Henry III after a conflict named for these people against forces led by Simon de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham. The first conflict named for these people forced King John to grant civil liberties to every individual.

bonuses.leadin: Wanda Landowska was a 20th century virtuoso on this instrument. For ten points each:
answers: harpsichord [accept clavecin or cembalo; prompt on spinet or muselar or virginal]
(Giuseppe) Domenico Scarlatti [do not accept or prompt on Pietro Filippo Scarlatti]
parts: Name this keyboard instrument widely used in the Renaissance and Baroque periods. This keyboard instrument, which produces sound by the plucking of strings, was replaced by the piano in the late 18th century.
This Italian Baroque composer and harpsichordist is best remembered for their 555 keyboard sonatas. This composer’s father, Alessandro, composed the operas Telemaco and La Griselda.
Domenico Scarlatti was also a talented player of this instrument. J. S. Bach walked 250 miles to listen to another virtuoso player of this instrument, whose “pipe” variety can be found in churches.

bonuses.leadin: This actor played a jingle writer on Two and a Half Men before a feud with series creator Chuck Lorre caused this actor to be replaced by Ashton Kutcher. For ten points each:
answers: Charlie Sheen [or Carlos Irwin Estévez; prompt on Estévez or Sheen]
President of the United States [or POTUS]
parts: Name this actor who played a nearly-blind pitcher for the Cleveland Indians in Major League. They also appeared in the music video for Lil Pump’s song “Drug Addicts.”

Charlie’s brother Emilio Estevez played Andrew, “the athlete,” in this 1984 John Hughes movie. This movie centers on five drastically different high school students who are all in detention and are instructed to write about “who [they] think [they] are.”

Charlie and Emilio’s father Martin Sheen played Jed Bartlet, a character with this profession, on The West Wing. James Adomain played George W. Bush, a holder of this position, in the 2008 comedy Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay.
answers_formatted: Charlie Sheen [or Carlos Irwin Estévez; prompt on Estévez or Sheen]

bonuses.leadin: Vienna waits for you, besiegers. For ten points each:
answers: Suleiman I [accept Suleiman the Magnificent or Suleiman the Lawgiver, prompt on Suleiman alone]
Matthias Corvinus [accept Matthias I, prompt on Matthias alone]
parts: This onion turban-wearing Ottoman sultan besieged Vienna in 1529. This longest reigning Ottoman ruler reformed the law code and presided over the peak of Ottoman power.
An apocryphal story holds that the residents of Vienna took inspiration from the Ottoman flag for these crescent-shaped French pastries after the Ottoman defeat in the 1683 siege of Vienna.
In 1485, this King of Hungary actually succeeded in capturing Vienna. This son of John Hunyadi established the Black Army, one of the earliest professional armies in Europe.
answers_formatted: Suleiman I [accept Suleiman the Magnificent or Suleiman the Lawgiver, prompt on Suleiman alone]
Matthias Corvinus [accept Matthias I, prompt on Matthias alone]
acceptable: Suleiman the Lawgiver, prompt on Suleiman alone
Matthias I, prompt on Matthias alone

bonuses.leadin: This Flower-Fruit Mountain-dwelling character is capable of 72 earthly transformations. For ten points each:
answers: jade [accept Jade Emperor, the novel mentioned is Dream of the Red Chamber.]
parts: Name this character who steals the Peaches of Immortality and is buried under a mountain by the Buddha.
In Journey to the West, Sun Wukong helps Tang Sanzang, a Buddhist monk from this country, obtain holy scriptures. Journey to the West is considered one of this Asian country’s Four Classic Novels.

Sun Wukong is appointed to the position of guardian of the aforementioned Peaches of Immortality by a god named to be an “Emperor” of this substance. In another of the Four Great Classics, Jia Baoyu is born with a piece of this substance in his mouth.
answers_formatted: jade [accept Jade Emperor, the novel mentioned is Dream of the Red Chamber.]
acceptable: Jade Emperor, the novel mentioned is Dream of the Red Chamber.

bonuses.leadin: An entry in this collection is titled “How Segregation Caused Your Traffic Jam.” For ten points each:
answers: The New York Times [or The Times]
parts: Name this collection that consists of essays, school curricula, poems, and podcasts documenting and analyzing the history of black people in the United States. It is titled after the year in which enslaved Africans first arrived in Virginia.

Tom Cotton, a senator from this state, proposed to prohibit K-12 schools from using federal funds to implement the 1619 Project in their curriculum. 2016 presidential candidate and political commentator Mike Huckabee previously served as governor of this state.

This newspaper’s magazine printed the original 1619 Project. This newspaper, which competes with the Wall Street Journal in its namesake city, operates under the motto “All the News That’s Fit to Print.”

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions about the process of desalination:
answers: reverse osmosis [do not accept or prompt on “osmosis”]
parts: Desalination is most often applied to this substance in order to make it drinkable. This substance, which makes up oceans, rivers, and lakes, is necessary for human survival.
Some desalination plants utilize this process, in which pressure is applied to saltwater in order to force water to areas of lower salt concentration, filtering out the ions across a membrane.
Along with freshwater, this type of solution results from the reverse osmosis. This type of solution, resulting from high salt concentration in water, is sometimes used to preserve foods.
answers_formatted: reverse osmosis [do not accept or prompt on "“osmosis”"]

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about the Songhai Empire:
parts: One of the Songhai Empire’s most important cities was this settlement on the Niger River. This major trading hub was the site of Sankore University and the Djinguereber [Jin-gay-reb-er] mosque.

Unlike other African civilizations, the Songhai Empire was an early convert to this religion. Although Songhai leaders Sonni Ali and Muhammad Askia were ardent followers of this religion, other religions were accepted in the empire.
The Songhai Empire fell after being defeated by armies under Judar Pasha from this country at the Battle of Tondibi. Two rival dynasties in this country signed the Treaty of Tadla.

bonuses.leadin: A 1970 artwork by Larry Rivers titled I Like [this painting] in Blackface consists of a doubled version of this painting with contrasting colors as a denouncement of the social conditions of Black Americans. For ten points each:
answers: Olympia [accept I Like Olympia in Blackface or A Modern Olympia]
Diego Velázquez [or Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez]
parts: Name this painting depicting the title nude prostitute lying on a bed and staring at the viewer. Paul Cezanne’s [say-ZAHN’s] Modern version of this painting depicts the black maid in this painting dramatically unveiling its central figure.

This artist’s Spirit of the Dead Watching was noted by critics for its similarity to Olympia, with the maid in Olympia being replaced by a ghost. This artist’s other paintings include Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

The Irish painter Louis le Brocquy drew inspiration from many paintings, including Olympia and this artist’s Rokeby Venus, for his painting A Family. This Spanish Golden Age artist also painted the Infanta Margarita and her entourage in Las Meninas.
answers_formatted: Olympia [accept I Like Olympia in Blackface or A Modern Olympia]
Diego Velázquez [or Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez]
acceptable: Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez

bonuses.leadin: These cellular structures line the inner surface of the Fallopian tubes. For ten points each:
answers: acetylation [do not accept or prompt on “methylation”]
parts: Name these cellular structures that aid in the movement of the protozoa Paramecium. Unlike flagella, these organelles are small and hair-like.

Cilia and flagella are made of these structures, which form the cytoskeleton along with actin filaments and intermediate filaments. These structures are also used to create spindle fibers during mitosis.

During post-translational modification, tubulin can undergo this process on its lysine 40. When this process occurs with histones, a certain functional group is added in order to synthesize euchromatin.

bonuses.leadin: In Lakota myth, the trickster Iktomi is one of these animals. For ten points each:
answers: Hero Twins [accept Naayéé’neizghání AND Tóbájíshchíní or Slayer of Monsters AND Born for Water]
parts: Name this animal. To the Hopi, a “Grandmother” one of these animals lives underground and offers helpful advice to those in need, while in Navajo myth, a female one teaches humans to weave.
In the Diné Bahane’, Spider Woman aids these figures, the sons of Changing Woman, in defeating a group of monsters. In another myth system, figures of this name battle the bat god Camazotz.

Spider Woman tells the Hero Twins that their father is not a cactus, but actually the personification of this thing. He is called Johanaa’ei, or “the one who rules the day,” while his sister, the moon, is called “the one who rules the night.”
answers_formatted: Hero Twins [accept Naayéé’neizghání AND Tóbájíshchíní or Slayer of Monsters AND Born for Water]
acceptable: Slayer of Monsters AND Born for Water

bonuses.leadin: Yellowcake is an intermediate process during the purification of this element. For ten points each:
parts: Name this element with atomic symbol U. This element’s 235 isotope is used in nuclear reactors, and this element is the heaviest naturally occurring element.

Uranium undergoes nuclear fission when it exceeds this value, which is reached when the effective neutron multiplication factor is equal to 1. Beryllium is often used as a neutron reflector to decrease this value.
When uranium does not undergo nuclear fission, it naturally decays through this process. The radiation from this process is blocked by a sheet of paper.

bonuses.leadin: This text contains hymns known as Sohila that are recited at bedtime. For ten points each:
parts: Name this religious text that was written in the Gurmukhi script. This text, which is divided by ragas, begins with the Ik Onkar character at the start of the Mul Mantar passage.
The Adi Granth is the central religious text of this monotheistic religion based in India founded by Guru Nanak. Some of this religion’s members are recognizable by their turbans.

Members of Sikhism wear five articles of faith, including a wooden one of these called a kangha. This object is supposed to clean the hair and remind Sikhs that their lives should be organized and tidy.

bonuses.leadin: The Scottsboro Boys were falsely accused of assaulting two women after being arrested in this state. For ten points each:
answers: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
parts: Name this state. The Scottsboro Boys were tried in this state’s Supreme Court, which is located in its capital of Montgomery.

This organization offered to have Clarence Darrow defend the Scottsboro Boys at an appeal trial. This organization, one of the oldest civil rights organizations in the US, was founded by W.E.B DuBois and publishes the magazine The Crisis.
This civil rights activist raised money to cover the Scottsboro Boys’ legal costs. In 1955, this activist was chosen over Claudette Colvin to lead another protest.
answers_formatted: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
acceptable: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

bonuses.leadin: This author took his name from the banana plant that grew outside his hut. For ten points each:
answers: Narrow Road to the Deep North [or Narrow Road to the Interior, accept Oku no Hosomichi]
parts: Name this author of many haikus, including one about the splash of water produced when a frog jumps into an ancient pond. He opened a travelogue with the phrase “the months and days are the travellers of eternity.”
Basho used the haibun style, a mix of prose and haikus, to write this aforementioned travelogue. A poem from this collection describes “the rough sea / stretching out towards Sado / the Milky Way.”
Basho lived in this city for much of his life. This city, the current capital of Japan, was then known as Edo.
answers_formatted: Narrow Road to the Deep North [or Narrow Road to the Interior, accept Oku no Hosomichi]
acceptable: Narrow Road to the Deep North
Narrow Road to the Interior, accept Oku no Hosomichi

bonuses.leadin: The hypothetical Paleo-Balkan languages may have been a part of this larger language family. For ten points each:
parts: Name this language family that includes the Germanic and Romance languages. Some languages from this largest language family are English, Sanskrit, and Russian.
In Proto-Indo-European, these parts of speech were notoriously complex. These words convey action, and some examples in English include “walk” and “run.”

While conjugation describes inflection of verbs, this other word refers to the inflection of anything else, including nouns, pronouns, and adjectives. Latin has five of these entities, which are grouped by ending and gender.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of Act 1 of a play set in this location, Maria Josefa desires to be married at sea after escaping the room she’s usually locked in. For ten points each:
answers: The House of Bernarda Alba [or La Casa de Bernarda Alba, accept equivalents]
parts: Name this location that titles a play where Adela hangs herself after she thinks her love interest Pepe El Romano was shot by her domineering mother.
The House of Bernarda Alba was penned by this Spanish author. Another work in his Rural Trilogy sees Leonardo Felix and the Groom killing each other over their love of the Bride in Blood Wedding.
A Yevgeny Yevtushenko poem compares Lorca to this title windmill-attacking “Ingenious Gentleman” of a Miguel de Cervantes novel.
answers_formatted: The House of Bernarda Alba [or La Casa de Bernarda Alba, accept equivalents]
acceptable: La Casa de Bernarda Alba, accept equivalents
